trans-unit.source: Connect a web app in Azure App Service to Redis Cache via the Memcache protocol | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Connect a web app in Azure App Service to Redis Cache via the Memcache protocol | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Connect a web app in Azure App service to Redis Cache using the Memcache protocol
trans-unit.target: Connect a web app in Azure App service to Redis Cache using the Memcache protocol

trans-unit.source: Connect a web app in Azure App Service to Redis Cache via the Memcache protocol
trans-unit.target: Connect a web app in Azure App Service to Redis Cache via the Memcache protocol

trans-unit.source: In this article, you'll learn how to connect a WordPress web app in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> to <link><linkText>Azure Redis Cache[12]</linkText><title></title></link> using the <link><linkText>Memcache[13]</linkText><title></title></link> protocol.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you'll learn how to connect a WordPress web app in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> to <link><linkText>Azure Redis Cache[12]</linkText><title></title></link> using the <link><linkText>Memcache[13]</linkText><title></title></link> protocol.

trans-unit.source: If you have an existing web app that uses a Memcached server for in-memory caching, You can migrate it to Azure App Service and use the first-party caching solution in Microsoft Azure with little or no change to your application code.
trans-unit.target: If you have an existing web app that uses a Memcached server for in-memory caching, You can migrate it to Azure App Service and use the first-party caching solution in Microsoft Azure with little or no change to your application code.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, you can use your existing Memcache expertise to create highly scalable, distributed apps in Azure App Service with Azure Redis Cache for in-memory caching, while using popular application frameworks such as .NET, PHP, Node.js, Java, and Python.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, you can use your existing Memcache expertise to create highly scalable, distributed apps in Azure App Service with Azure Redis Cache for in-memory caching, while using popular application frameworks such as .NET, PHP, Node.js, Java, and Python.

trans-unit.source: App Service Web Apps enables this application scenario with the Web Apps Memcache shim, which is a local Memcached server that acts as a Memcache proxy for caching calls to Azure Redis Cache.
trans-unit.target: App Service Web Apps enables this application scenario with the Web Apps Memcache shim, which is a local Memcached server that acts as a Memcache proxy for caching calls to Azure Redis Cache.

trans-unit.source: This enables any app that communicates using the Memcache protocol to cache data with Redis Cache.
trans-unit.target: This enables any app that communicates using the Memcache protocol to cache data with Redis Cache.

trans-unit.source: This Memcache shim works at the protocol level, so it can be used by any application or application framework as long as it communicates using the Memcache protocol.
trans-unit.target: This Memcache shim works at the protocol level, so it can be used by any application or application framework as long as it communicates using the Memcache protocol.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: The Web Apps Memcache shim can be used with any application provided it communicates using the Memcache protocol.
trans-unit.target: The Web Apps Memcache shim can be used with any application provided it communicates using the Memcache protocol.

trans-unit.source: For this particular example, the reference application is a Scalable WordPress site which can be provisioned from the Azure Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: For this particular example, the reference application is a Scalable WordPress site which can be provisioned from the Azure Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps outlined in these articles:
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps outlined in these articles:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Provision an instance of the Azure Redis Cache Service[1]</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Provision an instance of the Azure Redis Cache Service[1]</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Deploy a Scalable WordPress site in Azure[0]</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Deploy a Scalable WordPress site in Azure[0]</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Once you have the Scalable WordPress site deployed and a Redis Cache instance provisioned you will be ready to proceed with enabling the Memcache shim in Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Once you have the Scalable WordPress site deployed and a Redis Cache instance provisioned you will be ready to proceed with enabling the Memcache shim in Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Enable the Web Apps Memcache shim
trans-unit.target: Enable the Web Apps Memcache shim

trans-unit.source: In order to configure Memcache shim, you must create three app settings.
trans-unit.target: In order to configure Memcache shim, you must create three app settings.

trans-unit.source: This can be done using a variety of methods including the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>, the <link><linkText>Old Portal[3]</linkText><title></title></link>, the <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell Cmdlets[5]</linkText><title></title></link> or the <link><linkText>Azure Command-Line Interface[5]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This can be done using a variety of methods including the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>, the <link><linkText>Old Portal[3]</linkText><title></title></link>, the <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell Cmdlets[5]</linkText><title></title></link> or the <link><linkText>Azure Command-Line Interface[5]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this post, I’m going to use the <link><linkText>Azure Portal[4]</linkText><title></title></link> to set the app settings.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this post, I’m going to use the <link><linkText>Azure Portal[4]</linkText><title></title></link> to set the app settings.

trans-unit.source: The following values can be retrieved from Settings blade of your Redis Cache instance.
trans-unit.target: The following values can be retrieved from Settings blade of your Redis Cache instance.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Settings Blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Settings Blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add REDIS_HOST app setting
trans-unit.target: Add REDIS_HOST app setting

trans-unit.source: The first app setting you need to create is the REDIS\_HOST app setting.
trans-unit.target: The first app setting you need to create is the REDIS\_HOST app setting.

trans-unit.source: This setting sets the destination to which the shim forwards the cache information.
trans-unit.target: This setting sets the destination to which the shim forwards the cache information.

trans-unit.source: The value required for the REDIS_HOST app setting can be retrieved from the Properties blade of your Redis Cache instance.
trans-unit.target: The value required for the REDIS_HOST app setting can be retrieved from the Properties blade of your Redis Cache instance.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Host Name</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Host Name</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Set the key of the app setting to REDIS\_HOST and the value of the app setting to the hostname of the Redis Cache instance.
trans-unit.target: Set the key of the app setting to REDIS\_HOST and the value of the app setting to the hostname of the Redis Cache instance.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web App AppSetting REDIS_HOST</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web App AppSetting REDIS_HOST</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add REDIS_KEY app setting
trans-unit.target: Add REDIS_KEY app setting

trans-unit.source: The second app setting you need to create is the REDIS\_KEY app setting.
trans-unit.target: The second app setting you need to create is the REDIS\_KEY app setting.

trans-unit.source: This setting provides the authentication token required to securely access the Redis Cache instance.
trans-unit.target: This setting provides the authentication token required to securely access the Redis Cache instance.

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve the value required for the REDIS_KEY app setting from the Access keys blade of the Redis Cache instance.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve the value required for the REDIS_KEY app setting from the Access keys blade of the Redis Cache instance.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Primary Key</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Primary Key</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Set the key of the app setting to REDIS\_KEY and the value of the app setting to the Primary Key of the Redis Cache instance.
trans-unit.target: Set the key of the app setting to REDIS\_KEY and the value of the app setting to the Primary Key of the Redis Cache instance.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Website AppSetting REDIS_KEY</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Website AppSetting REDIS_KEY</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add MEMCACHESHIM_REDIS_ENABLE app setting
trans-unit.target: Add MEMCACHESHIM_REDIS_ENABLE app setting

trans-unit.source: The last app setting is used to enable the Memcache Shim in Web Apps, which uses the REDIS_HOST and REDIS_KEY to connect to the Azure Redis Cache and forward the cache calls.
trans-unit.target: The last app setting is used to enable the Memcache Shim in Web Apps, which uses the REDIS_HOST and REDIS_KEY to connect to the Azure Redis Cache and forward the cache calls.

trans-unit.source: Set the key of the app setting to MEMCACHESHIM\_REDIS\_ENABLE and the value to true.
trans-unit.target: Set the key of the app setting to MEMCACHESHIM\_REDIS\_ENABLE and the value to true.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web App AppSetting MEMCACHESHIM_REDIS_ENABLE</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web App AppSetting MEMCACHESHIM_REDIS_ENABLE</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once you are done adding the three (3) app settings, click Save.
trans-unit.target: Once you are done adding the three (3) app settings, click Save.

trans-unit.source: Enable Memcache extension for PHP
trans-unit.target: Enable Memcache extension for PHP

trans-unit.source: In order for the application to speak the Memcache protocol, it's necessary to install the Memcache extension to PHP--the language framework for your WordPress site.
trans-unit.target: In order for the application to speak the Memcache protocol, it's necessary to install the Memcache extension to PHP--the language framework for your WordPress site.

trans-unit.source: Download the php_memcache Extension
trans-unit.target: Download the php_memcache Extension

trans-unit.source: Browse to <link><linkText>PECL[6]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Browse to <link><linkText>PECL[6]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Under the caching category, click <link><linkText>memcache[7]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Under the caching category, click <link><linkText>memcache[7]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Under the downloads column click the DLL link.
trans-unit.target: Under the downloads column click the DLL link.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>PHP PECL Website</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>PHP PECL Website</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Download the Non-Thread Safe (NTS) x86 link for the version of PHP enabled in Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Download the Non-Thread Safe (NTS) x86 link for the version of PHP enabled in Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: (Default is PHP 5.4)
trans-unit.target: (Default is PHP 5.4)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>PHP PECL Website Memcache Package</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>PHP PECL Website Memcache Package</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enable the php_memcache extension
trans-unit.target: Enable the php_memcache extension

trans-unit.source: After you download the file, unzip and upload the php\_memcache.dll into the d:\\home\\site\\wwwroot\\bin\\ext\\ directory.
trans-unit.target: After you download the file, unzip and upload the php\_memcache.dll into the d:\\home\\site\\wwwroot\\bin\\ext\\ directory.

trans-unit.source: After the php_memcache.dll is uploaded into the web app, you need to enable the extension to the PHP Runtime.
trans-unit.target: After the php_memcache.dll is uploaded into the web app, you need to enable the extension to the PHP Runtime.

trans-unit.source: To enable the Memcache extension in the Azure Portal, open the Application Settings blade for the web app, then add a new app setting with the key of PHP\_EXTENSIONS and the value bin\\ext\\php_memcache.dll.
trans-unit.target: To enable the Memcache extension in the Azure Portal, open the Application Settings blade for the web app, then add a new app setting with the key of PHP\_EXTENSIONS and the value bin\\ext\\php_memcache.dll.

trans-unit.source: If the web app needs to load multiple PHP extensions, the value of PHP_EXTENSIONS should be a comma delimited list of relative paths to DLL files.
trans-unit.target: If the web app needs to load multiple PHP extensions, the value of PHP_EXTENSIONS should be a comma delimited list of relative paths to DLL files.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web App AppSetting PHP_EXTENSIONS</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web App AppSetting PHP_EXTENSIONS</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once finished, click Save.
trans-unit.target: Once finished, click Save.

trans-unit.source: Install Memcache WordPress plugin
trans-unit.target: Install Memcache WordPress plugin

trans-unit.source: You can also download the <link><linkText>Memcached Object Cache Plugin</linkText><title></title></link> from WordPress.org.
trans-unit.target: You can also download the <link><linkText>Memcached Object Cache Plugin</linkText><title></title></link> from WordPress.org.

trans-unit.source: On the WordPress plugins page, click Add New.
trans-unit.target: On the WordPress plugins page, click Add New.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>WordPress Plugin Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>WordPress Plugin Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the search box, type memcached and press Enter.
trans-unit.target: In the search box, type memcached and press Enter.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>WordPress Add New Plugin</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>WordPress Add New Plugin</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Find Memcached Object Cache in the list, then click Install Now.
trans-unit.target: Find Memcached Object Cache in the list, then click Install Now.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>WordPress Install Memcache Plugin</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>WordPress Install Memcache Plugin</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enable the Memcache WordPress plugin
trans-unit.target: Enable the Memcache WordPress plugin

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions in this blog on <link><linkText>How to enable a Site Extension in Web Apps[8]</linkText><title></title></link> to install Visual Studio Online.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions in this blog on <link><linkText>How to enable a Site Extension in Web Apps[8]</linkText><title></title></link> to install Visual Studio Online.

trans-unit.source: In the wp-config.php file, add the following code above the stop editing comment near the end of the file.
trans-unit.target: In the wp-config.php file, add the following code above the stop editing comment near the end of the file.

trans-unit.source: Once this code has been pasted, monaco will automatically save the document.
trans-unit.target: Once this code has been pasted, monaco will automatically save the document.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to enable the object-cache plugin.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to enable the object-cache plugin.

trans-unit.source: This is done by dragging and dropping object-cache.php from wp-content/memcached folder to the wp-content folder to enable the Memcache Object Cache functionality.
trans-unit.target: This is done by dragging and dropping object-cache.php from wp-content/memcached folder to the wp-content folder to enable the Memcache Object Cache functionality.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Locate the memcache object-cache.php plugin</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Locate the memcache object-cache.php plugin</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now that the object-cache.php file is in the wp-content folder, the Memcached Object Cache is now enabled.
trans-unit.target: Now that the object-cache.php file is in the wp-content folder, the Memcached Object Cache is now enabled.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Enable the memcache object-cache.php plugin</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Enable the memcache object-cache.php plugin</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Verify the Memcache Object Cache plugin is functioning
trans-unit.target: Verify the Memcache Object Cache plugin is functioning

trans-unit.source: All of the steps to enable the Web Apps Memcache shim are now complete.
trans-unit.target: All of the steps to enable the Web Apps Memcache shim are now complete.

trans-unit.source: The only thing left is to verify that the data is populating your Redis Cache instance.
trans-unit.target: The only thing left is to verify that the data is populating your Redis Cache instance.

trans-unit.source: Enable the non-SSL port support in Azure Redis Cache
trans-unit.target: Enable the non-SSL port support in Azure Redis Cache

trans-unit.source: At the time of writing this article, the Redis CLI does not support SSL connectivity, thus the following steps are necessary.
trans-unit.target: At the time of writing this article, the Redis CLI does not support SSL connectivity, thus the following steps are necessary.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Portal, browse to the Redis Cache instance that you created for this web app.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Portal, browse to the Redis Cache instance that you created for this web app.

trans-unit.source: Once the cache's blade is open, click the Settings icon.
trans-unit.target: Once the cache's blade is open, click the Settings icon.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Settings Button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Settings Button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Access Ports from the list.
trans-unit.target: Select Access Ports from the list.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Access Port</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Access Port</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click No for Allow access only via SSL.
trans-unit.target: Click No for Allow access only via SSL.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Access Port SSL Only</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Access Port SSL Only</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You will see that the NON-SSL port is now set.
trans-unit.target: You will see that the NON-SSL port is now set.

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Redis Access Portal Non-SSL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Redis Cache Redis Access Portal Non-SSL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Connect to Azure Redis Cache from redis-cli
trans-unit.target: Connect to Azure Redis Cache from redis-cli

trans-unit.source: This step assumes that redis is installed locally on your development machine.
trans-unit.target: This step assumes that redis is installed locally on your development machine.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Install Redis locally using these instructions[9]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Install Redis locally using these instructions[9]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Open your command-line console of choice and type the following command:
trans-unit.target: Open your command-line console of choice and type the following command:

trans-unit.source: Replace the *** with the actual xxxxx.redis.cache.windows.net hostname and the *** with the access key for the cache, then press Enter. Once the CLI has connected to the Redis Cache instance, issue any redis command. In the screenshot below, I’ve chosen to list the keys.
trans-unit.target: Replace the *** with the actual xxxxx.redis.cache.windows.net hostname and the *** with the access key for the cache, then press Enter. Once the CLI has connected to the Redis Cache instance, issue any redis command. In the screenshot below, I’ve chosen to list the keys.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connect to Azure Redis Cache from Redis CLI in Terminal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connect to Azure Redis Cache from Redis CLI in Terminal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The call to list the keys should return a value.
trans-unit.target: The call to list the keys should return a value.

trans-unit.source: If not, try navigating to the web app and trying again.
trans-unit.target: If not, try navigating to the web app and trying again.

trans-unit.source: Conclusion
trans-unit.target: Conclusion

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: The WordPress app now has a centralized in-memory cache to aid in increasing throughput.
trans-unit.target: The WordPress app now has a centralized in-memory cache to aid in increasing throughput.

trans-unit.source: Remember, the Web Apps Memcache Shim can be used with any Memcache client regardless of programming language or application framework.
trans-unit.target: Remember, the Web Apps Memcache Shim can be used with any Memcache client regardless of programming language or application framework.

trans-unit.source: To provide feedback or to ask questions about the Web Apps Memcache shim, post to <link><linkText>MSDN Forums[10]</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Stackoverflow[11]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To provide feedback or to ask questions about the Web Apps Memcache shim, post to <link><linkText>MSDN Forums[10]</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Stackoverflow[11]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: What's changed
trans-unit.target: What's changed

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and its impact on existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <link><linkText>Azure App Service and its impact on existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <link><linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <link><linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>
